title: InDesign Question
content:
Hi all

I want the same image to appear on every page of a document. My question is if I put it on a master page instead of on every single page individually, does that reduce the file size when building a pdf?

Thanks in advance  
Regards

comments.content:
Hi Kiko,

no, it shouldn’t affect the file size.  
But there are other reasons for having repeating elements on a master page – it’s just so much tidier.  
F

I wouldn’t think it would...but I echo Florian’s comment. Makes it a lot neater, and a lot easier to change with consistency.

Peace,  
JT

<cite>no, it shouldn’t affect the file size.</cite>

Ok, that’s what I thought so.  
Thanks for reply.

The proof is in the pudding of course.

A fast test:  
Document 10 pages.  
Image (to be once on every page): 119282 bytes  
Document with image placed separately on each page: 2238884 bytes  
Document with image on Master A, 10 pages based on Master A: 20444950 bytes  
Difference: almost 9%.

Draw your own conclusions.

. . .  
Bert Vanderveen BNO

I found that rather than Exporting to pdf, printing the same file to PS and distilling reduces the image overhead to nearly nothing — apparently storing it only once.

In one case I sent a client vastly downsampled proofs — up to the point he started complaining — because of a single huge image that occurred every other few pages. Even after downsampling, the PDF exceeded 10 MB. After his final approval, I made a PS file for the printer, converted it to PDF to double check — and it was about 5 MB, with the highest image rez possible. Embarrassed looks all around.

Your mileage might vary.
Yes, I was referring to the final PDF file size. The InDesign document might grow bigger, depending on the way you build it.
